content: this is dmg and we're making gates so a video 50 metal gates were probably
about less than 10% of the way through the list I've got at the moment so we're
gonna take a piece of cardboard that's five by five centimeters and I'm just
going to measure in about half a centimeter each from in from each side
and drawn in a square so just right from the edge rulers and complete the end in
a square there and then I'm gonna find the middle so I'm going to measure a
right to the middle so but two centimeters in from the inner square so
two and a half centimeters in from the edge and then a half a centimeters is
called a centimeter on each side and then I'm gonna cut out those rectangles
that are created so just with a craft knife cutter I'm just gonna jump ahead
here because you don't need to see this you see me cut through cardboard a
million times but ya just rip right the way through so this is double layer
cardboard that I'm using and what we're gonna do now is we're going to grab some
kabob skewers these are ones I've chopped off bits before so that's why
they're not as long and I'm just gonna shove them through the corrugation to
the other side same give a good shove and push them all the way to the end and
just be careful not to rip the cardboard just push it through slowly and this
will again just jumped ahead so I've put through all on the ones and then we just
add hot glue down the sides and I had a problem with a camera angle here so some
of this is a little bit off-screen I apologize for that and we base it just
using hot glue to stick the commands yours to the outer edge and cutting off
the excess in the bottom so now I have the gate formation and I've got to cut
off the existing an arch so I'm using the toilet paper roll to measure where
the curve would be as I've done with all the other doors and then it's just a
matter of lopping off the excess kebab sticks
at the points where the arch would be this formed the arch and now I've got to
create the metal band around the edge so to do that I cut out a long about 16
centimeter strip of cardboard hot glue down the side and all across the top of
the band skewers and again I apologize for this but the camera angle is
slightly off so when I attach this cardboard you won't be able to see it
but basically just wraps around the side over the top and down the other side you
can just see it popping in there and it's as simple as that to create the
main gate arch so from here we're now going to just get a little to about one
centimeter of pieces of kebab skewer and hot glue just down the side from the
lower rung there and plot that on and turn it over make sure it's on the
opposite side of the one you just did and stick on the other one and that just
forms the the gate handle and now we're going to use the toilet paper roll again
on some card stock cut out the card stock lot or four quarter so we're left
with the bases we've done with all the other doors glue on the bottom and stick
it onto the base nice and easy okay so now we've got the gate and we've got the
cap interested in what we're doing so what I'm doing here is I'm applying
the mixture of black and white the gray and instead of dabbing it on I'm
actually smearing it on so I'm dragging the sponge over the cardboard and the
command skewers and that yeah so instead of it looking like stone it'll look like
metal because I've dragged to the paint on and we'll continue this process now
with some other colors but just make sure that you you get a
a good even gray to that and doesn't worry if there's a little bit of black
the shadow is nice and then I do dab it onto the base just to give it that stone
look for the floor so into the paint I'm gonna mix in some red and some brown and
smoosh it all up and it's a little bit too red and too pink there with a white
that's come into it so I'm just gonna add a little bit more Brown bit more
Brown there we go and mix it up again so we've got a sort of pinky brown color
and then lightly drag it on parts of gate so we don't want to cover it we
just want to sort of hit it in certain areas to get that sort of pinky Brown
look of the oxidation on the iron gate so we're now or after that or we're
going to add more Brown just by itself I'm just gonna mix the brown I'm gonna
do sort of a brown stippling a DAB so this dabbing makes it look like the
crustiness of the of the of the rust that's occuring so you don't drag it you
dab it on and that just furthers the effect so in the end you have a rusty
gate so what I've got just here I just went got a little bit of gray and some
white just touched a little bit of highlights on the gate and and you know
each little thing that you do adds a little bit extra and then mix a little
bit of the gray with the brown and dab it on again so I didn't do do boots of
speed here just so that it would be easier for you to to see how it's done
and there we go so there's the rusty gate now I'm just gonna add with boots
of speed the rivets with white paint so it looks like there's rivets going
through and I did add some hot glue in the inside there just to hold those
kabob skewers in place so that's how I make miniature metal gates and if you'd
